awd_titl_txt: EAPSI: Probing Phase Transitions in Magnetic Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores changes in the magnetic properties of materials that are important to our understanding of superconductors. Superconductors are materials that allow the flow of electricity without electrical resistance. These materials are widely used in MRI machines, MagLev trains, and scientific equipment. A better understanding will lead to cheaper and more practical equipment, as well as new technologies. Working in the lab of the expert sample grower Professor Kazuyoshi Yoshimura in Kyoto will enable rapid sample production and study.

This project proposes to use nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) techniques to study spin fluctuations in CsCo2Se2, a material with a two dimensional electronic structure, near an antiferromagnetic phase transition. This will be done by measuring the spin lattice relaxation rate (T1-1 ) as a function of temperature. This measurement will be repeated at each nuclear site in the crystal. 

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

por.por_cntn:
During the Summer of 2016, Matthew Lawson participated in research funded jointly by the NSF and JSPS at Kyoto univeristy, under the supervision of Professor Kazuyoshi Yoshimura. As a condensed matter physicist, Matthew studies unusual materials and their properties.

Our initial project was to study CsCo2Se2, however due to unexpected difficulties obtaining or synthesizing a sample, we quickly switched to Nuclear Magnetic Resonance studies of Hf2Te2P. We specifically attempted to detect quantum oscillations, a effect only visible at extremely low temperatures and high magnetic fields. Quantum oscillations are sensitive probes of the behavior of the electrons in a material, and specifically if those electrons are behaving in accordance with "fermi liquid theory" or not. If not, observing quantum oscillations is a good way to to measure how far off the behavior of the electrons in the material is from our theories. If detected, this would have been the first NMR measurement to detect quantum oscillations. 


We were unable to resolve any quantum oscillations above the level of the inherent noise in our experiment. We were able to establish that observing quantum oscillations in Hf2Te2P would require higher magnetic fields and/or lower temperatures than we were able to achieve. Further work on this material could be done at a facility like the national high magnetic field lab in Tallahassee, FL, or the high B/T facility in Gainesville, FL. Our work, setting a lower bound on the ratio of magnetic field to temperatures required to detect quantum oscillations via NMR helps justify future work at these NSF facilities, since only there would the effect be detectable.
